PRIMARY SURVEY — AIRWAY
• Question: Airway compromised (GCS < 8 or pooling/obstruction)?
• Signs: snoring/stridor/gurgling, absent gag, copious secretions, facial trauma.
• If YES → Prepare RSI (pre-oxygenate, suction, checklist, backup airway).

ACTION — SECURE AIRWAY
• RSI with cervical precautions if trauma.
• After tube: confirm (capnography), set vent, start sedation/analgesia, OG/NG if safe.
• Suction pooled secretions; consider aspiration prophylaxis.

PRIMARY SURVEY — BREATHING
• Question: SpO₂ < 94% or increased work of breathing?
• If YES → oxygen (nasal/prongs → face mask → NRBM; NIV if indicated and airway protected).

ACTION — OXYGENATION/VENTILATION
• Titrate O₂ to SpO₂ ≥ 94% (or target per comorbidity).
• If persistent hypoxemia/ventilatory failure → escalate (NIV/IMV) and evaluate causes.

PRIMARY SURVEY — CIRCULATION
• Question: Hypotension (SBP < 100 mmHg or MAP < 65 mmHg)?
• If YES → resuscitate.

ACTION — RESUSCITATION
• Fluid bolus with isotonic crystalloid; reassess perfusion.
• If MAP < 65 after fluids or fluid-averse → start norepinephrine and search for shock cause.

RAPID CHECK — GLUCOSE
• Question: Hypoglycemia (glucose < 70 mg/dL)?

ACTION — HYPOGLYCEMIA
• Give IV dextrose; recheck in 5–10 min; treat underlying cause (insulin/sulfonylurea, sepsis, adrenal).

RAPID CHECK — SEIZURES
• Question: Ongoing seizures or witnessed convulsions/NCSE suspected?

ACTION — SEIZURE CONTROL
• Benzodiazepine first-line; load antiepileptic as indicated.
• Protect airway and ventilation; avoid hypoglycemia/hypoxia/hyperthermia.

SCREEN — TOXIDROMES/REVERSIBLES
• Suspicion of opioid/benzodiazepine toxicity, Wernicke’s, CO, organophosphates, etc.?

ACTION — TARGETED REVERSAL
• Consider naloxone if opioid toxicity; flumazenil only in select cases; give thiamine before glucose if deficiency suspected.
• Decontamination/supportive care per agent.

NEURO IMAGING TRIAGE
• Red flags: focal deficits, head trauma/anticoagulation, acute severe headache, new lateralizing signs, fever with focality.
• If ANY red flag → urgent non-contrast CT brain.

ACTION — URGENT NCCT BRAIN
• Rule out hemorrhage/mass effect/large infarct; involve neurology/neurosurgery early.
• Manage BP/ICP per findings; ensure antithrombotic history captured.

INITIAL LAB PANEL
• ABG; electrolytes (Na⁺/K⁺/Ca²⁺/Mg²⁺); renal/liver panel; CBC; glucose; ECG.
• Consider: ammonia, TSH, cortisol, toxicology, cultures based on context.

ICP CONCERN?
• Signs: Cushing triad, anisocoria, papilledema, decerebrate posturing, very low GCS.
• If YES → start ICP-lowering bundle.

ACTION — ICP BUNDLE
• Head-up 30°, neutral neck; adequate sedation/analgesia; PaCO₂ 35–40; mannitol or hypertonic saline as indicated; avoid hypotension/hypoxia.
• Arrange urgent imaging and specialist review.

CATEGORIZE ETIOLOGY
• Infection (fever, meningism, sepsis), Metabolic/Endocrine (Na⁺, Ca²⁺, uremia, hepatic failure, hypo/hyperthyroid, adrenal), Structural (ICH/SAH/ischemia/mass), Psychogenic (dx of exclusion).
• Choose likely category to see next actions.

PATHWAY — METABOLIC/ENDOCRINE
• Correct Na⁺ (rate limits), Ca²⁺, Mg²⁺; manage uremia/hepatic encephalopathy; check TSH/free T4, cortisol; treat DKA/HHS as indicated.

PATHWAY — STRUCTURAL CNS
• If ICH/SAH/large stroke/mass: BP/ICP targets; neurology/neurosurgery consult; reversal of anticoagulation if needed; DVT prophylaxis planning.

PATHWAY — PSYCHOGENIC
• Only after organic causes excluded; check for inconsistencies; psych consult; avoid unnecessary sedatives.

UNCLEAR ETIOLOGY — NEXT STEPS
• Reassess exam; sedation hold; repeat glucose/ABG/electrolytes; collateral history/med list; delirium screen; consider EEG if persistent altered state.

DISPOSITION/REASSESSMENT
• Continue targeted pathway; document major decisions and times; plan monitoring and repeat neuro checks.
